      • enableMSProof

        public void enableMSProof(boolean enable)

      • makeObjectMSProof

        public void makeObjectMSProof(IGObject aObject,
                     SourceLocation aSrc)
                       throws ZamiaException
        This method is a prerequisite for an elegant and straightforward 2-step solution of driver merging.
        This method resolves the conflict of drivers when multiple processes write to the same signal as a whole.

        For those signals driven from multiple processes as a whole (e.g. 'sigA <= "0010"', but not 'sigA(1 to 2)<= "0"') -- and for these signals only !!! -- this method adds an exact chained copy of signal's target driver to the context of the process, so that during execution this copy is used instead of the target driver (which resides one step deeper in the stack (in the architecture context) and thus will be hidden behind the copy).

        This way each driving process has a unique copy (functionally equivalent to the target driver), which allows us to avoid collisions of signal change events in IGSignalDriver.setNextValue(org.zamia.instgraph.IGStaticValue, org.zamia.SourceLocation, IGSimProcess). This collision happens when different processes use the same driver (which is exactly the target driver) during execution of IGSignalChangeRequest-s and rewrite each others' nextValues they set to the IGSignalDriver. Hence the naming: make object Multiple Sources Proof.

        Note that there is no need for such a trick when a part of a signal is driven, for a range driver is already a unique driver. Also a chained (mapped) copy will not be created when there is only 1 'whole signal driver'.

        Since this method is only run during simulator initialization and hopefully for a very limited number of signals, this solution is expected to be faster than handling the conflict repetitively during interpreter code execution.

        Parameters:
        aObject -
        aSrc -
        Throws:
        ZamiaException
